patterns: dark brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Late blight in potato is caused by Phytophthora infestans. Symptoms include dark brown to black lesions on leaves, water-soaked spots on stems, white fungal growth on leaf undersides, and tuber rot. Control by applying fungicides such as Mancozeb, Metalaxyl, or Chlorothalonil, practicing crop rotation, and removing infected plant debris.

patterns: brown to black circular lesions on leaves

responses.message: Early blight in potato is caused by Alternaria solani. Symptoms include brown to black circular lesions with concentric rings on leaves, leaf yellowing, leaf drop, and stem lesions. Manage early blight using fungicides such as Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb, crop rotation, and removal of infected leaves.

patterns: blackened, soft rot at stem base

responses.message: Blackleg in potato is caused by Pectobacterium spp. (formerly Erwinia). Symptoms include blackened soft rot at stem base, wilting and toppling of plants, and foul odor. Control by planting certified disease-free seed, avoiding injury to tubers, and ensuring good drainage.

Common scab in potato is caused by Streptomyces species. Symptoms include rough, corky lesions on tuber surfaces, reducing tuber quality. Prevent common scab by maintaining soil moisture during tuber formation and using resistant varieties.

patterns: small black dots on tuber surface

responses.message: Black dot disease is caused by Colletotrichum coccodes. Symptoms are small black dots on tuber surfaces causing superficial dark lesions with no internal damage. Control with crop rotation, fungicide application, and removing infected debris.

patterns: gray fuzzy mold on stems and leaves

responses.message: Grey mold in potato is caused by Botrytis cinerea. Symptoms include gray fuzzy mold on stems, leaves, flower blight, and tuber decay. Manage by improving ventilation, removing infected tissue, and applying appropriate fungicides.

patterns: clusters of small green insects on stems

responses.message: Aphids commonly infest potato plants causing sap sucking, leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides.
Wireworms are larvae that feed on potato tubers causing holes and tunneling. Manage wireworms by crop rotation, soil treatment, and use of insecticides if necessary.

patterns: grayish-purple fuzzy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in onion is caused by Peronospora destructor. Symptoms include pale yellow spots on leaves, grayish-purple fuzzy growth on leaf undersides, and leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as metalaxyl or mancozeb, ensuring good air circulation, and avoiding overhead irrigation.

patterns: small brown to black spots on leaves

responses.message: Necrotic spot in onion is caused by Alternaria porri. Symptoms include small brown to black spots on leaves with yellowing and leaf tip necrosis leading to premature leaf drop. Manage using fungicides like mancozeb and removing infected plant debris.

patterns: white fluffy fungal growth at bulb base

responses.message: White rot in onion is caused by Sclerotium cepivorum. Symptoms include yellowing and wilting of leaves, white fluffy fungal growth at bulb base, and bulb rot. Control by crop rotation, fungicide soil treatment, and planting disease-free sets.

Bacterial soft rot in onion is caused by Pectobacterium carotovorum. Symptoms include soft, watery rot of bulbs with foul odor and yellowing, collapsing leaves. Control by avoiding bulb injury, proper storage conditions, and use of bactericides.

patterns: yellow or silver streaks on leaves

responses.message: Thrips infestation in onion causes yellow or silver streaks on leaves, leaf curling, stunted growth, and reduced bulb size. Control using insecticidal soaps, neem oil sprays, or recommended insecticides.

patterns: clusters of small green insects on leaves and stems

responses.message: Aphids suck sap from onion leaves and stems causing leaf curling, yellowing, sticky honeydew, and promoting sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.

patterns: brown discoloration at base of bulb

responses.message: Fusarium basal rot in onion is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. cepae. Symptoms include yellowing and wilting leaves, brown discoloration at bulb base, and soft, rotten bulbs. Control by planting disease-free seed, crop rotation, and fungicide soil treatment.

patterns: dark brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Late blight in tomato is caused by Phytophthora infestans. Symptoms include dark brown to black lesions on leaves, water-soaked spots on stems, white fungal growth on leaf undersides, and fruit rot. Control by applying fungicides such as Mancozeb, Metalaxyl, or Chlorothalonil, practicing crop rotation, and removing infected plant debris.

patterns: brown to black circular lesions on leaves

responses.message: Early blight in tomato is caused by Alternaria solani. Symptoms include brown to black circular lesions with concentric rings on leaves, leaf yellowing, leaf drop, and stem lesions. Manage early blight using fungicides such as Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb, crop rotation, and removal of infected leaves.

Bacterial spot in tomato is caused by Xanthomonas spp. Symptoms include small water-soaked spots on leaves, dark brown lesions on stems, fruit spots, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and practicing good sanitation.

Fusarium wilt in tomato is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici. Symptoms include yellowing leaves, wilting, brown discoloration in vascular tissue, and stunted growth. Control by planting resistant varieties, crop rotation, and using fungicides.

Verticillium wilt in tomato is caused by Verticillium spp. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing of lower leaves, vascular browning, and plant decline. Manage through crop rotation and resistant varieties.

Powdery mildew in tomato is caused by Oidium spp. Symptoms include white powdery spots on leaves, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

patterns: gray fuzzy mold on leaves and stems

responses.message: Botrytis blight (gray mold) in tomato is caused by Botrytis cinerea. Symptoms include gray fuzzy mold on leaves and stems, flower and fruit blight, and stem lesions. Control by removing infected tissues and applying fungicides.
Aphids infest tomato plants causing sap sucking, leaf curling, sticky honeydew, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides.

Whiteflies on tomato cause yellowing leaves, honeydew secretion leading to sooty mold, and vector viral diseases. Control by using yellow sticky traps, insecticidal soaps, and encouraging natural predators.

patterns: brown to black circular lesions on leaves

responses.message: Early blight in brinjal is caused by Alternaria solani. Symptoms include brown to black circular lesions with concentric rings on leaves, leaf yellowing, leaf drop, and stem lesions. Manage early blight using fungicides such as Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb, crop rotation, and removal of infected leaves.

Fusarium wilt in brinjal is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. melongenae. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing of leaves, brown discoloration in vascular tissue, and stunted growth. Control by planting resistant varieties, crop rotation, and fungicide application.

Bacterial spot in brinjal is caused by Xanthomonas vesicatoria. Symptoms include small water-soaked spots on leaves, dark brown lesions on stems, fruit spots, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and practicing good sanitation.

Powdery mildew in brinjal is caused by Oidium spp. Symptoms include white powdery spots on leaves, leaf distortion, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

Anthracnose in brinjal is caused by Colletotrichum spp. Symptoms include dark sunken lesions on fruits, leaf spots, and fruit rot. Control by removing infected fruits, applying fungicides, and maintaining field sanitation.

patterns: clusters of small green insects on stems and leaves

responses.message: Aphids suck sap causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold development on brinjal. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.

patterns: small white flying insects on undersides of leaves

responses.message: Whiteflies infest brinjal leaves causing yellowing, honeydew secretion leading to sooty mold, and can transmit viral diseases. Control by using yellow sticky traps, insecticidal soaps, and introducing natural predators.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in brinjal is caused by Cercospora spp. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers and dark margins causing leaf yellowing and drop. Control by removing infected leaves and applying appropriate fungicides.

patterns: yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges

responses.message: Black rot in cabbage is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris. Symptoms include yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges, blackening of veins, leaf yellowing and wilting, and soft rot in vascular tissues. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and copper-based bactericides.

patterns: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on underside of leaves

responses.message: Downy mildew in cabbage is caused by Peronospora brassicae. Symptoms include yellow patches on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on underside of leaves, leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as mancozeb or metalaxyl, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead irrigation.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in cabbage is caused by Cercospora brassicae. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers and brown to black margins causing leaf yellowing and dropping. Control by removing infected leaves and applying fungicides.

Clubroot in cabbage is caused by Plasmodiophora brassicae. Symptoms include swollen, distorted roots, wilting plants, stunted growth, and yellowing leaves. Control by crop rotation, liming soil to increase pH, and using resistant varieties.

Powdery mildew in cabbage is caused by Erysiphe cruciferarum. Symptoms include white powdery growth on leaves, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

patterns: brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Blight in cabbage is caused by Alternaria brassicae. Symptoms include brown to black lesions on leaves, leaf blight, and defoliation. Manage blight by fungicide applications and field sanitation.

patterns: clusters of small green or gray insects

responses.message: Aphids infest cabbage causing leaf curling, sticky honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides and encourage natural predators.
Cabbage worms (larvae of Pieris brassicae) feed on cabbage leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges

responses.message: Black rot in cauliflower is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris. Symptoms include yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges, blackening of veins, leaf yellowing and wilting, and soft rot in vascular tissues. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and copper-based bactericides.

patterns: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on underside of leaves

responses.message: Downy mildew in cauliflower is caused by Peronospora brassicae. Symptoms include yellow patches on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on underside of leaves, leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as mancozeb or metalaxyl, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead irrigation.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in cauliflower is caused by Cercospora brassicae. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers and brown to black margins causing leaf yellowing and dropping. Control by removing infected leaves and applying fungicides.

Clubroot in cauliflower is caused by Plasmodiophora brassicae. Symptoms include swollen, distorted roots, wilting plants, stunted growth, and yellowing leaves. Control by crop rotation, liming soil to increase pH, and using resistant varieties.

Powdery mildew in cauliflower is caused by Erysiphe cruciferarum. Symptoms include white powdery growth on leaves, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

patterns: brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Blight in cauliflower is caused by Alternaria brassicae. Symptoms include brown to black lesions on leaves, leaf blight, and defoliation. Manage blight by fungicide applications and field sanitation.

patterns: clusters of small green or gray insects

responses.message: Aphids infest cauliflower causing leaf curling, sticky honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides and encourage natural predators.
Cabbage worms (larvae of Pieris brassicae) feed on cauliflower leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Powdery mildew in okra is caused by Erysiphe cichoracearum. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves, leaf curling, and reduced growth. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and ensuring good air circulation.

Fusarium wilt in okra is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. vasinfectum. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free seeds, soil solarization, crop rotation, and fungicide application.
Root-knot nematodes in okra cause root galls, stunted plants, yellowing leaves, and poor yield. Manage by crop rotation with non-host plants, soil fumigation, and using resistant varieties.

patterns: small brown to black spots on leaves

responses.message: Bacterial leaf spot in okra is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. malvacearum. Symptoms include small brown to black spots on leaves with yellow halos leading to leaf drop. Control with copper-based bactericides and proper sanitation.
Powdery scurf in okra causes brownish scurf on pods, rough surfaces, and uneven pod development. Control by applying fungicides and practicing crop rotation.

patterns: clusters of small green insects on stems and leaves

responses.message: Aphids suck sap causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold development on okra. Control aphids by using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encouraging natural predators.

Whiteflies on okra cause yellowing leaves, honeydew secretion leading to sooty mold, and may vector viral diseases. Control by using yellow sticky traps, insecticidal soaps, and encouraging natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on okra leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: white powdery coating on leaves and stems

responses.message: Powdery mildew in peas is caused by Erysiphe pisi. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves and stems, leaf curling, and reduced plant vigor. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

Fusarium wilt in peas is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. pisi. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, brown discoloration in vascular tissues, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free seed, soil solarization, crop rotation, and fungicide application.

patterns: brown to black lesions on leaves and stems

responses.message: Ascochyta blight in peas is caused by Didymella pinodes and related fungi. Symptoms include brown to black lesions on leaves and stems, leaf drop, and stem cankers. Control by crop rotation, fungicide applications, and removal of infected plant debris.

Root rot in peas is caused by soil-borne pathogens such as Rhizoctonia solani and Pythium spp. Symptoms include yellowing and wilting plants, root decay, and poor growth. Control by soil drainage improvement, crop rotation, and fungicide soil treatments.

Bacterial blight in peas is caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. pisi. Symptoms include water-soaked spots on leaves, leaf yellowing, and bacterial ooze. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and good field sanitation.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest peas causing leaf curling, distortion, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Pea weevil larvae damage pea leaves and pods resulting in notched edges and reduced yield. Control by using insecticides and practicing crop rotation.
Powdery scurf on peas causes brown scurf patches and rough pod surface. Control by applying fungicides and crop rotation.

patterns: white powdery coating on leaves and stems

responses.message: Powdery mildew in beans is caused by Erysiphe polygoni. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves and stems, leaf curling, and reduced growth. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and ensuring good air circulation.

Anthracnose in beans is caused by Colletotrichum lindemuthianum. Symptoms include dark sunken lesions on pods, leaf spots, and pod rot. Control by removing infected plant debris, applying recommended fungicides, and crop rotation.

Bacterial blight in beans is caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. phaseolicola. Symptoms include water-soaked spots on leaves, brown lesions on stems, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and practicing field sanitation.

Root rot in beans is caused by soil-borne fungi including Rhizoctonia solani and Pythium spp. Symptoms include yellowing, wilting, root decay, and stunted growth. Control by improving soil drainage, crop rotation, and fungicide treatments.

Fusarium wilt in beans is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. phaseoli. Symptoms are wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular browning, and stunted growth. Control by using resistant varieties, crop rotation, and soil treatments.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest beans causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Thrips cause silvery streaks on bean leaves, deformed flowers, and black speckling. Control thrips using insecticidal soaps or recommended insecticides.
Caterpillars feed on bean leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Bacterial spot in chilli is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. Symptoms include water-soaked spots on leaves, brown lesions on stems, fruit spots, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seeds, copper-based bactericides, and practicing good sanitation.

patterns: white powdery coating on leaves and stems

responses.message: Powdery mildew in chilli is caused by Leveillula taurica. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves and stems, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and ensuring good air circulation.

Fusarium wilt in chilli is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. capsici. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by planting resistant varieties, crop rotation, and soil treatment.

Anthracnose in chilli is caused by Colletotrichum capsici. Symptoms include dark sunken lesions on fruits, leaf spots, and fruit rot. Control by removing infected plant parts, applying fungicides, and maintaining field sanitation.

patterns: gray fuzzy mold on flowers and leaves

responses.message: Botrytis blight in chilli is caused by Botrytis cinerea. Symptoms include gray fuzzy mold on flowers and leaves, flower blight, and fruit rot. Control by removing infected tissue and applying appropriate fungicides.

Aphids infest chilli causing sap sucking, leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Thrips cause silvery streaks on chilli leaves, deformed flowers, and black speckling. Control with insecticidal soaps or labeled insecticides.
Caterpillars feed on chilli leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Powdery mildew in carrot is caused by Erysiphe heraclei. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves, leaf curling, and reduced plant vigor. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

patterns: brown to black spots with concentric rings on leaves

responses.message: Alternaria leaf spot in carrot is caused by Alternaria dauci. Symptoms include brown to black spots with concentric rings on leaves, leaf yellowing, and leaf drop. Control by using fungicides such as mancozeb and removal of infected plant debris.

Bacterial blight in carrot is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. carotae. Symptoms include water-soaked lesions on leaves, leaf yellowing, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and practicing good sanitation.
Root-knot nematodes cause galls on carrot roots leading to stunted growth and yellowing leaves. Manage by crop rotation, soil fumigation, and using resistant varieties.

Cavity spot in carrot is caused by Pythium spp. Symptoms include sunken lesions and discolored spots on roots leading to poor root quality. Control by improving soil drainage, crop rotation, and fungicide soil treatments.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest carrot plants causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on carrot leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Powdery mildew in cucumber is caused by Podosphaera xanthii and Erysiphe cichoracearum. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves, leaf curling, yellowing, and reduced growth. Control by applying sulfur or potassium bicarbonate fungicides and improving air circulation.

patterns: gray-purple fuzzy growth on underside of leaves

responses.message: Downy mildew in cucumber is caused by Pseudoperonospora cubensis. Symptoms include yellow angular spots on leaves, gray-purple fuzzy growth on undersides, leaf curling, and browning. Control by using fungicides like metalaxyl and mancozeb, ensuring good airflow, and avoiding overhead watering.

Bacterial wilt in cucumber is caused by Erwinia tracheiphila. Symptoms include wilting vines, yellowing leaves, bacterial ooze in stems, and plant collapse. Control by managing cucumber beetles which spread the disease and removing infected plants.

patterns: brown to black circular spots on leaves

responses.message: Alternaria leaf spot in cucumber is caused by Alternaria cucumerina. Symptoms include brown to black circular spots on leaves, yellowing, and leaf drop. Control by fungicide applications and removal of infected plant debris.

Gummy stem blight in cucumber is caused by Didymella bryoniae. Symptoms include dark lesions on stems, gum exudation, and wilting vines. Manage by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, fungicide sprays, and removal of infected debris.
Cucumber beetles feed on leaves, flowers, and fruits causing holes and yellowing. They also vector bacterial wilt. Control by handpicking, using insecticides, and applying row covers.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest cucumber causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides and encourage natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on cucumber leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: yellow spots on upper leaf surface
white to grayish downy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in spinach is caused by Peronospora farinosa f.sp. spinaciae. Symptoms include yellow spots on upper leaf surface, white to grayish downy growth on leaf undersides, and leaf curling and distortion. Control by using resistant varieties, applying fungicides like metalaxyl or mefenoxam, and improving air circulation.

Fusarium wilt in spinach is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. spinaciae. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and soil fungicide treatments.

Bacterial leaf spot in spinach is caused by Pseudomonas spp. Symptoms include small water-soaked spots on leaves, brown lesions, leaf yellowing, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and proper sanitation.

patterns: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in leafy greens is caused by various Peronospora species. Symptoms include yellow patches on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on leaf undersides, and leaf curling. Control by applying fungicides, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead watering.

Powdery mildew in leafy greens is caused by Erysiphe and related fungal species. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control using sulfur-based fungicides and promoting good air circulation.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in leafy greens is caused by Cercospora spp. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers, dark margins on leaves, leaf yellowing, and drop. Control by fungicide application and removal of infected leaves.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest leafy greens causing leaf curling, sticky honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on leafy greens causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Powdery mildew in bottle gourd is caused by Erysiphe cichoracearum. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves, leaf curling, and reduced growth. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and ensuring good air circulation.

patterns: gray-purple fuzzy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in bitter gourd is caused by Pseudoperonospora cubensis. Symptoms include yellow angular spots on leaves, gray-purple fuzzy growth on leaf undersides, leaf curling, and browning. Control with fungicides like metalaxyl and mancozeb, improve air circulation, and avoid overhead watering.

Angular leaf spot in ridge gourd is caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. lachrymans. Symptoms include angular brown spots on leaves, leaf yellowing, and leaf drop. Control with copper-based bactericides and removal of infected leaves.

Gummy stem blight in pumpkin is caused by Didymella bryoniae. Symptoms include dark lesions on stems, gum exudation, and wilting vines. Manage by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, fungicide sprays, and removal of infected debris.

intents.plant: bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, pumpkin
patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Sap-sucking pests like aphids, whiteflies, and mealybugs infest bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, and pumpkin causing leaf curling, sticky honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control these pests using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and promoting natural predators.

intents.plant: bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, pumpkin

responses.message: Caterpillars feed on leaves of bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, and pumpkin causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: yellow spots on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in bottle gourd is caused by Pseudoperonospora cubensis. Symptoms include yellow spots on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on leaf undersides, and leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as metalaxyl, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead irrigation.

Powdery mildew in bitter gourd is caused by Erysiphe cichoracearum. Symptoms include white powdery spots on leaves, leaf distortion, and premature leaf drop. Control by sulfur-based fungicides and ensuring good ventilation.

Viral mosaic disease in ridge gourd causes mottled yellow and green leaves, stunted growth, and distorted fruits. No chemical control exists; manage by controlling insect vectors like whiteflies and using resistant varieties.

patterns: white powdery coating on leaves and stems

responses.message: Powdery mildew in pumpkin is caused by Erysiphe cichoracearum and Podosphaera xanthii. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves and stems, leaf curling, and reduced growth. Control by applying sulfur fungicides and improving air circulation.

intents.plant: bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, pumpkin

responses.message: Fusarium wilt affects bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, and pumpkin caused by Fusarium oxysporum species. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular browning, and stunted growth. Control through planting disease-free seed, crop rotation, and fungicide application.

intents.plant: bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, pumpkin

responses.message: Root-knot nematodes cause galls on roots of bottle gourd, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, and pumpkin leading to stunted plants, yellowing leaves, and poor yield. Manage by crop rotation, soil fumigation, and using resistant varieties.

patterns: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in radish is caused by Peronospora manshurica. Symptoms include yellow patches on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on leaf undersides, and leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as mancozeb and metalaxyl, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead irrigation.

patterns: yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges

responses.message: Black rot in radish is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris. Symptoms include yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges, blackening of veins, leaf yellowing, and wilting. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and copper-based bactericides.

patterns: brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Blight in radish is caused by Alternaria brassicae. Symptoms include brown to black lesions on leaves, leaf blight, and defoliation. Control by fungicide applications and field sanitation.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in radish is caused by Cercospora spp. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers, brown to black margins, leaf yellowing, and dropping. Control by applying fungicides and removing infected leaves.
Root-knot nematodes cause galls on radish roots leading to stunted plants, yellowing leaves, and poor root development. Manage by crop rotation, soil fumigation, and resistant varieties.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest radish causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Cabbage worms feed on radish leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on leaf undersides

responses.message: Downy mildew in turnip is caused by Peronospora brassicae. Symptoms include yellow patches on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on leaf undersides, and leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as mancozeb or metalaxyl, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead watering.

patterns: yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges

responses.message: Black rot in turnip is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris. Symptoms include yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges, blackening of veins, leaf yellowing, and wilting. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and copper-based bactericides.

patterns: brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Blight in turnip is caused by Alternaria brassicae. Symptoms include brown to black lesions on leaves, leaf blight, and defoliation. Control by fungicide applications and field sanitation.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in turnip is caused by Cercospora spp. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers, brown to black margins, leaf yellowing, and dropping. Control by applying fungicides and removing infected leaves.
Root-knot nematodes cause galls on turnip roots leading to stunted plants, yellowing leaves, and poor root development. Manage by crop rotation, soil fumigation, and resistant varieties.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects

responses.message: Aphids infest turnip causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Cabbage worms feed on turnip leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Bacterial spot in capsicum is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. Symptoms include water-soaked spots on leaves, brown lesions on stems, fruit spots, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seeds, copper-based bactericides, and practicing good sanitation.

patterns: white powdery coating on leaves and stems

responses.message: Powdery mildew in capsicum is caused by Leveillula taurica. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves and stems, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and ensuring good air circulation.

Fusarium wilt in capsicum is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. capsici. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by planting resistant varieties, crop rotation, and soil treatment.

Anthracnose in capsicum is caused by Colletotrichum capsici. Symptoms include dark sunken lesions on fruits, leaf spots, and fruit rot. Control by removing infected plant parts, applying fungicides, and maintaining field sanitation.

patterns: gray fuzzy mold on flowers and leaves

responses.message: Botrytis blight in capsicum is caused by Botrytis cinerea. Symptoms include gray fuzzy mold on flowers and leaves, flower blight, and fruit rot. Control by removing infected tissue and applying appropriate fungicides.

Aphids infest capsicum causing sap sucking, leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Thrips cause silvery streaks on capsicum leaves, deformed flowers, and black speckling. Control with insecticidal soaps or labeled insecticides.
Caterpillars feed on capsicum leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Powdery mildew in drumstick is caused by Erysiphe polygoni. Symptoms include white powdery coating on leaves, leaf curling, and reduced growth. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

Fusarium wilt in drumstick is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. mori. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free seedlings, crop rotation, and fungicide application.

patterns: brown to black spots on leaves

responses.message: Leaf spot in drumstick is caused by Cercospora moricola. Symptoms include brown to black spots on leaves, yellowing, and leaf drop. Control by fungicide application and removal of infected leaves.
Root-knot nematodes infest drumstick causing root galls, yellowing leaves, and stunted growth. Manage by crop rotation, soil solarization, and resistant varieties.

Aphids feed on drumstick sap causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids using insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on drumstick leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: green powdery mold on casing soil

responses.message: Green mold in mushrooms is caused by Trichoderma species. Symptoms include green powdery mold on casing soil surface, reduced mushroom yield, and contamination of beds. Control by maintaining proper hygiene, using sterilized casing material, and applying fungicides in severe cases.

patterns: wet, bubble-like lesions on mushroom caps

responses.message: Wet bubble disease in mushrooms is caused by Mycogone perniciosa. Symptoms include wet, bubble-like lesions on caps, distorted mushrooms, and poor fruiting bodies. Control by removing infected substrates and maintaining sterile growing conditions.

Dry bubble disease in mushrooms is caused by Verticillium fungicola. Symptoms include dry, deformed caps, discoloration, and malformed fruit bodies. Control by sanitation, removing infected mushrooms, and proper compost pasteurization.

patterns: yellow to brown water-soaked lesions on caps

responses.message: Bacterial blotch in mushrooms is caused by Pseudomonas tolaasii. Symptoms include yellow to brown water-soaked lesions on caps, slimy spots, and unpleasant odor. Control by reducing casing moisture, improving ventilation, and sanitizing equipment.

patterns: whitish mycelial growth on mushroom caps

responses.message: Verticillium blight in mushrooms is caused by Lecanicillium fungicola. Symptoms include whitish mycelial growth on caps, brown spots, and fruit body collapse. Control by sanitation, removing infected mushrooms, and fungicide application.

Trichoderma species cause green mold contamination in mushrooms, characterized by white to green aerial mycelium, rapid spread on substrate, and suppressed mushroom growth. Control by proper sterilization of compost and casing material, and maintaining hygiene.

Fusarium wilt in sweet potato is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. batatas. Symptoms include wilting vines, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free slips, crop rotation, and soil fungicide treatment.

Root rot in sweet potato is caused by soil pathogens including Rhizopus and Pythium species. Symptoms include soft, rotten roots, brown lesions on roots, and wilting plants. Control by ensuring good soil drainage, crop rotation, and fungicidal soil treatments.

Scab disease in sweet potato is caused by Streptomyces scabies. Symptoms include rough, corky lesions on roots leading to reduced quality. Control by maintaining soil moisture during root formation and using resistant varieties.
Wireworms feed on sweet potato roots causing holes and tunnels, leading to poor development and reduced yield. Manage by crop rotation, soil treatment, and insecticide application if necessary.
Aphids infest sweet potato causing leaf curling, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.

Whiteflies infest sweet potato causing yellowing leaves, sticky honeydew leading to sooty mold, and may vector viral diseases. Control by using yellow sticky traps, insecticidal soaps, and promoting natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on sweet potato leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges

responses.message: Black rot in broccoli is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris. Symptoms include yellow V-shaped lesions on leaf edges, blackening of veins, leaf yellowing and wilting, and soft rot in vascular tissues. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and copper-based bactericides.

patterns: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
white downy growth on underside of leaves

responses.message: Downy mildew in broccoli is caused by Peronospora brassicae. Symptoms include yellow patches on upper leaf surface, white downy growth on underside of leaves, leaf curling and dieback. Control by applying fungicides such as mancozeb or metalaxyl, improving air circulation, and avoiding overhead irrigation.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in broccoli is caused by Cercospora brassicae. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers and brown to black margins causing leaf yellowing and dropping. Control by removing infected leaves and applying fungicides.

Clubroot in broccoli is caused by Plasmodiophora brassicae. Symptoms include swollen, distorted roots, wilting plants, stunted growth, and yellowing leaves. Control by crop rotation, liming soil to increase pH, and using resistant varieties.

Powdery mildew in broccoli is caused by Erysiphe cruciferarum. Symptoms include white powdery growth on leaves, leaf curling, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying sulfur-based fungicides and improving air circulation.

patterns: brown to black lesions on leaves

responses.message: Blight in broccoli is caused by Alternaria brassicae. Symptoms include brown to black lesions on leaves, leaf blight, and defoliation. Manage blight by fungicide applications and field sanitation.

patterns: clusters of small green or gray insects

responses.message: Aphids infest broccoli causing leaf curling, sticky honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides and encourage natural predators.
Cabbage worms (larvae of Pieris brassicae) feed on broccoli leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

Bacterial blight in celery is caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. apii. Symptoms include water-soaked spots on leaves, brown lesions on stems, leaf yellowing, and leaf drop. Control by using disease-free seed, copper-based bactericides, and maintaining sanitation.

Fusarium wilt in celery is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. apii. Symptoms include wilting, yellowing leaves, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free seed, crop rotation, and soil fungicide treatments.

Late blight in celery is caused by Septoria apiicola. Symptoms include dark brown lesions on leaves, water-soaked spots on stems, and leaf drop. Control by applying fungicides, crop rotation, and removing infected debris.

patterns: gray fuzzy mold on leaves and stems

responses.message: Botrytis blight in celery is caused by Botrytis cinerea. Symptoms include gray fuzzy mold on leaves and stems, leaf blight, and stem lesions. Control by improving air circulation, removing infected tissues, and fungicide application.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects on stems

responses.message: Aphids infest celery causing sap sucking, leaf curling, sticky honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, or systemic insecticides and encourage natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on celery leaves causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).

patterns: orange to brown pustules on stems and spears

responses.message: Asparagus rust is caused by Puccinia asparagi. Symptoms include orange to brown rust pustules on stems and spears, yellow spots on foliage, and premature leaf drop. Control by applying fungicides, removing infected plant debris, and practicing crop rotation.

Fusarium wilt in asparagus is caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. asparagi. Symptoms include wilting spears, yellowing and browning of foliage, vascular discoloration, and stunted growth. Control by using disease-free crowns, crop rotation, and fungicide treatments.

patterns: small circular spots with gray centers
dark margins on stems and leaves

responses.message: Cercospora leaf spot in asparagus is caused by Cercospora asparagi. Symptoms include small circular spots with gray centers and dark margins on stems and leaves causing yellowing and leaf drop. Control by removing infected debris and applying fungicides.

Bacterial canker in asparagus is caused by Pseudomonas asparagi. Symptoms include sunken cankers on stems, brown lesions, wilting, and dieback. Control by using disease-free planting materials, sanitizing tools, and removing infected plants.

patterns: clusters of small green or black insects on stems

responses.message: Aphids infest asparagus causing leaf curling, sticky honeydew, and sooty mold development. Control aphids with insecticidal soaps, neem oil, systemic insecticides, and encourage natural predators.
Caterpillars feed on asparagus foliage causing holes and defoliation. Control by handpicking or using biological insecticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt).
